member.name: T:KGySoft.ComponentModel.NamespaceDoc

In KGy SOFT Drawing Libraries the KGySoft.ComponentModel namespace contains a single implementation.
For more KGySoft.ComponentModel types see the KGySoft.ComponentModel namespace of the KGy SOFT Core Libraries.
For the main KGy SOFT Drawing Libraries features see the KGySoft.Drawing and KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging namespaces.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Drawing.CursorHandle
member.summary:
Represents a windows cursor that supports colors and partial transparency. The instance can be passed to the System.Windows.Forms.Cursor constructor to create a new cursor.
See the Remarks section for details.

remarks.para: A instance can be created from an or instance by using the IconExtensions.ToCursorHandle and BitmapExtensions.ToCursorHandle extension methods.

This class can be used to create a custom Windows Forms Cursor that supports colors and partial transparency. Do keep a reference to this instance until the cursor is in use; otherwise, the cursor resources might be disposed too soon.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Drawing.DrawingModule
member.summary:
Represents the KGySoft.Drawing module.
See the Remarks section of the Initialize method for details.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Drawing.DrawingModule.Initialize
member.summary:
Initializes the KGySoft.Drawing module. On non-Windows platforms it makes possible to use System.Drawing types without editing the runtimeconfig.json file. Additionally, it initializes the resource manager for string resources and registers its central management in the LanguageSettings class.
See the Remarks section for details.

remarks.note: The module initializer is executed automatically when any member is accessed in the module for the first time. This method is public to able to trigger module initialization without performing any other operation. Normally you don't need to call it explicitly but it can be useful if you use the KGy SOFT Drawing Libraries in an application and you want to configure resource management on starting the application via the LanguageSettings class. In such case you can call this method before configuring language settings to make sure that the resources of the KGySoft.Drawing.dll are also affected by the settings.

If you use KGy SOFT Drawing Libraries from a non-Windows application, then make sure you call this method before using any System.Drawing type to prevent a without editing the runtimeconfig.json file. It is not necessary if you reference the .NET Framework build under Mono.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.Palette
member.summary:
Represents an indexed set of colors and provides efficient color lookup with caching. To create an instance use the static methods or the constructors.
See the Remarks section for details.

remarks.para: The class can be used to perform quick lookup operations (see GetNearestColor and GetNearestColorIndex methods) to find the closest matching palette entry to any color.

By default the lookup is performed by a slightly modified euclidean-like search but if the contains grayscale entries only, then it is optimized for finding the best matching gray shade based on human perception. To override this logic a custom lookup routine can be passed to the constructors.

If the instance is created without a custom lookup logic, then the search results for non-palette-entry colors are cached. The cache is optimized for parallel processing. The theoretical maximum of cache size (apart from the actual palette entries) is 2 x 218 but as soon as that limit is reached the amount of stored elements are halved so the cache is somewhat optimized to store the most recently processed colors.

In order to prevent caching you can pass a custom lookup logic to the constructors. It is expected to be fast (applying some direct mapping to a palette index, for example), or that it uses some custom caching (which should perform well also when queried concurrently).

The palette can have any number of colors but as the typical usage is quantizing colors for indexed bitmaps the typical maximum palette size is 256. Generally, the more color the palette has the slower are the lookups for non-palette colors that are not cached yet.

member.threadsafety: If there is no custom lookup logic passed to the constructors, then members of this type are guaranteed to be safe for multi-threaded operations. If this type is initialized with a custom lookup logic, then thread-safety depends on the custom lookup implementation.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.Palette.Count
member.summary: Gets the number of color entries in the current .

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.Palette.BackColor
member.summary: Gets the background color. If a lookup operation (GetNearestColor, GetNearestColorIndex) is performed with a color whose Color32.A field is equal to or greater than , and there is no exact match among the entries of this , then the color will be blended with this color before performing the lookup.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.Palette.AlphaThreshold
member.summary: If this has a transparent entry, then gets a threshold value for the Color32.A field, under which lookup operations will return the first transparent color (GetNearestColor) or the index of the first transparent color (GetNearestColorIndex) in the palette.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.Palette.Item(System.Int32)
member.summary: Gets the color entry of this at the specified .
member.param: The index of the color entry to be retrieved.
member.returns: A instance representing the color entry of the at the specified .
member.exception: must be equal to or greater than zero and less .

member.name: M:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.Palette.#ctor(KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.Color32[],KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.Color32,System.Byte,System.Func{KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.Color32,System.Int32})
member.summary:
Initializes a new instance of the class.
See the Remarks section of the class for details.
member.param: The color entries to be stored by this instance.

Specifies the background color for lookup operations (GetNearestColor, GetNearestColorIndex). When a lookup is performed with a color, whose Color32.A field is equal to or greater than , and there is no exact match among the , then the color to be found will be blended with this color before performing the lookup. The Color32.A field of the background color is ignored. This parameter is optional.
Default value: The default value of the type, which has the same RGB values as .

If there is at least one completely transparent color among , then specifies a threshold value for the Color32.A field, under which lookup operations will return the first transparent color (GetNearestColor) or the index of the first transparent color (GetNearestColorIndex). This parameter is optional.
Default value: 128.

A delegate specifying an optional custom lookup logic to obtain an index from by a instance. If specified, it must be thread-safe and it is expected to be fast. The results returned by the specified delegate are not cached. If , then GetNearestColor, GetNearestColorIndex will perform a sequential lookup by using a default logic and results will be cached. This parameter is optional.
Default value: .

member.name: M:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.Palette.#ctor(System.Drawing.Color[],System.Drawing.Color,System.Byte,System.Func{KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.Color32,System.Int32})
member.summary:
Initializes a new instance of the class.
See the Remarks section of the class for details.
member.param: The color entries to be stored by this instance. They will be converted to instances internally.

Specifies the background color for lookup operations (GetNearestColor, GetNearestColorIndex). When a lookup is performed with a color, whose Color32.A field is equal to or greater than , and there is no exact match among the , then the color to be found will be blended with this color before performing the lookup. The Color.A property of the background color is ignored. This parameter is optional.
Default value: , which has the same RGB values as .

If there is at least one completely transparent color among , then specifies a threshold value for the Color32.A field, under which lookup operations will return the first transparent color (GetNearestColor) or the index of the first transparent color (GetNearestColorIndex). This parameter is optional.
Default value: 128.

A delegate specifying an optional custom lookup logic to obtain an index from by a instance. If specified, it must be thread-safe and it is expected to be fast. The results returned by the specified delegate are not cached. If , then GetNearestColor, GetNearestColorIndex will perform a sequential lookup by using a default logic and results will be cached. This parameter is optional.
Default value: .

member.name: M:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.Palette.SystemDefault8BppPalette(KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.Color32,System.Byte)
member.summary:
Gets a instance that uses the system default 8-bit palette. On Windows this palette contains the 16 standard basic sRGB colors, the "web-safe" palette of 216 colors as well as 24 transparent entries.
See the Remarks section of the PredefinedColorsQuantizer.SystemDefault8BppPalette method for details and some examples.
member.param:
Specifies the background color for lookup operations (GetNearestColor, GetNearestColorIndex). When a lookup is performed with a color, whose Color32.A field is equal to or greater than , and there is no exact match among the palette entries, then the color to be found will be blended with this color before performing the lookup. The Color32.A field of the background color is ignored. This parameter is optional.
Default value: The default value of the type, which has the same RGB values as .

Specifies a threshold value for the Color32.A field, under which lookup operations will return the first transparent color (GetNearestColor) or the index of the first transparent color (GetNearestColorIndex). This parameter is optional.
Default value: 128.
member.returns: A instance that uses the system default 8-bit palette.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.Palette.SystemDefault4BppPalette(KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.Color32)
member.summary:
Gets a instance that uses the system default 4-bit palette. On Windows this palette consists of the 16 standard basic sRGB colors.
See the Remarks section of the PredefinedColorsQuantizer.SystemDefault4BppPalette method for details and some examples.
member.param:
Specifies the background color for lookup operations (GetNearestColor, GetNearestColorIndex). When a lookup is performed with a color with transparency, then the color to be found will be blended with this color before performing the lookup. The Color32.A field of the background color is ignored. This parameter is optional.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.BitmapDataFactory.CreateBitmapData(System.Drawing.Size,System.Drawing.Imaging.PixelFormat,KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.Color32,System.Byte)
member.summary:
Creates a managed with the specified and .
See the Remarks section for details.
member.param: The size of the bitmap data to create.
The desired pixel format of the bitmap data to create.

For pixel formats without alpha gradient support specifies the value of the returned instance. It does not affect the actual returned bitmap content. See the Remarks section for details. The alpha value (Color32.A field) of the specified background color is ignored. This parameter is optional.
Default value: The default value of the type, which has the same RGB values as .

For pixel formats without alpha gradient support specifies the value of the returned instance. See the Remarks section for details. This parameter is optional.
Default value: 128.
member.returns: A managed with the specified and .

remarks.para: All possible s are supported, regardless of the native support of the current operating system. When specifies a wide-color format (48/64 bit or 16 bit grayscale), then the returned instance will use the full 16-bit range of the color channels. This means a different raw content to Windows' wide-color instances, which use 13-bit channels. But this difference is transparent in most cases unless we access actual raw content by the ReadRaw and WriteRaw methods.
The parameter has no effect if has alpha gradient support and it does not affect the actual content of the returned instance. To set all pixels to a color use the Clear extension method.

If is zero, then setting a fully transparent pixel in a bitmap data with indexed or single-bit-alpha pixel format will blend the pixel to set with even if the bitmap data can handle transparent pixels.

If is 1, then the result color of setting a pixel of a bitmap data with indexed or single-bit-alpha pixel format will be transparent only if the color to set is completely transparent (has zero alpha).

If is 255, then the result color of setting a pixel of a bitmap data with indexed or single-bit-alpha pixel format will be opaque only if the color to set is completely opaque (its alpha value is 255).
For s without any alpha support the specified is used only to determine the source pixels to skip when another bitmap data is drawn into the returned instance.

If a pixel of a bitmap data without alpha gradient support is set by the IWritableBitmapData.SetPixel/IWritableBitmapDataRow.SetColor methods or by the IReadWriteBitmapDataRow indexer, and the pixel has an alpha value that is greater than , then the pixel to set will be blended with .

list.item: If represents an indexed format you can use the overload to specify the desired palette of the result.
You can use the ToBitmap extension method to convert the created to a instance.
To create an instance from a native use the GetReadWriteBitmapData extension method.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.ErrorDiffusionDitherer
member.summary:
Provides an implementation for error diffusion dithering. Use the static properties of this class to use predefined error diffusion filters or the constructor to create a custom one.
See the Remarks section for details and some image examples.

remarks.para: The constructor can be used to create an error diffusion ditherer using a custom matrix.
Use the static properties to obtain an instance with predefined parameters.

The class uses an adaptive dithering technique, which disperses the quantization error of each pixels to the neighboring ones. Thereby the strength of the dithering is automatically adjusted by the algorithm itself, which provides good results also for palettes with uneven color distribution (which is not the case for ordered dithering, for example).
As the dithered result of a pixel depends on the already processed pixels, the does not support parallel processing, which makes it slower than most of the other dithering methods.

The following table demonstrates the effect of the dithering:
Original imageQuantized image
Color hues with alpha gradient
Quantizing with system default 8 BPP palette, no dithering
Quantizing with system default 8 BPP palette and Floyd-Steinberg dithering
Quantizing with system default 8 BPP palette and Sierra 3 dithering
Quantizing with system default 8 BPP palette and Stevenson-Arce dithering
Grayscale color shades
Quantizing with black and white palette, no dithering
Quantizing with black and white palette and Floyd-Steinberg dithering
Quantizing with black and white palette and Sierra 3 dithering
Quantizing with black and white palette and Stevenson-Arce dithering

Calculation of the quantization error may happen in two ways. The publicly available algorithms usually calculate the error for each color channels, which usually provides good results with color palettes. However, when quantizing color images with a black and white or grayscale palette, this approach may fail. For example, if the quantizer returns black for a fully saturated blue pixel, the quantization error is zero on the red and green channels and 100% on the blue channel. The problem is that this error cannot be propagated to the neighboring pixels if they have the same color because adding any more blue to already fully saturated blue pixels will not change anything. Therefore, the can propagate quantization error by brightness based on human perception, which is more appropriate for palettes with grayscale colors. The tries to auto detect the strategy for each dithering session but this can be overridden by the ConfigureErrorDiffusionMode method.

The following table demonstrates the effect of different strategies:
Original imageQuantized image
Color hues with alpha gradient
Quantizing with system default 8 BPP palette and Floyd-Steinberg dithering, using error diffusion by RGB channels (the default strategy for non-grayscale palettes)
Quantizing with system default 8 BPP palette and Floyd-Steinberg dithering, using error diffusion by brightness
Color wheel
Quantizing with black and white palette and Floyd-Steinberg dithering, using blue background and error diffusion by brightness (the default strategy for grayscale palettes). All colors appear in the result with different patterns.
Quantizing with black and white palette and Floyd-Steinberg dithering, using blue background and error diffusion by RGB channels. The fully saturated colors turned completely black or white.

A typical artifact of error diffusion dithering is a ripple effect, which often appears in homogeneous areas of the dithered image. This is due to the fact that most filters propagate quantization errors mostly to right and down, whereas pixels are processed left-to-right in each line while lines are scanned top-down (raster processing). The ripple effect can be reduced if every second line is processed in the opposite direction (serpentine processing). You can use the ConfigureProcessingDirection method to obtain an with serpentine processing mode, which processes even lines left-to-right and odd lines right-to-left.

The following table demonstrates the effect of different processing directions:
Original imageQuantized image
Original test image "Cameraman"
Quantizing with black and white palette and Floyd-Steinberg dithering, using raster processing. The ripple effect is clearly visible on the coat.
Quantizing with black and white palette and Floyd-Steinberg dithering, using serpentine processing. The ripple effect is gone.
remarks.note: See the Examples section of the static properties for more examples.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.ErrorDiffusionDitherer.FloydSteinberg
member.summary:
Gets an instance using the original filter proposed by Floyd and Steinberg in 1975 when they came out with the idea of error diffusion dithering. Uses a small, 3x2 matrix so the processing is somewhat faster than by the other alternatives.
See the Examples section for some examples.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.ErrorDiffusionDitherer.JarvisJudiceNinke
member.summary:
Gets an instance using the filter proposed by Jarvis, Judice and Ninke in 1976. Uses a 5x3 matrix so the processing is slower than by the original Floyd-Steinberg filter but distributes errors in a wider range.
See the Examples section for some examples.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.ErrorDiffusionDitherer.Stucki
member.summary:
Gets an instance using the filter proposed by P. Stucki in 1981. Uses a 5x3 matrix so the processing is slower than by the original Floyd-Steinberg filter but distributes errors in a wider range.
See the Examples section for some examples.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.ErrorDiffusionDitherer.Burkes
member.summary:
Gets an instance using the filter proposed by D. Burkes in 1988. Uses a 5x2 matrix, which is actually the same as the first two lines of the matrix used by the filter.
See the Examples section for some examples.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.ErrorDiffusionDitherer.Sierra3
member.summary:
Gets an instance using the three-line filter proposed by Frankie Sierra in 1989. Uses a 5x3 matrix so this is the slowest Sierra filter but this disperses errors to the furthest among them.
See the Examples section for some examples.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.ErrorDiffusionDitherer.Sierra2
member.summary:
Gets an instance using the two-line filter proposed by Frankie Sierra in 1990. Uses a 5x2 matrix so this somewhat faster than the three-line version and still provides a similar quality.
See the Examples section for some examples.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.ErrorDiffusionDitherer.SierraLite
member.summary:
Gets an instance using a small two-line filter proposed by Frankie Sierra. Uses a 3x2 matrix so it has the same performance as the Floyd-Steinberg algorithm and also produces a quite similar result.
See the Examples section for some examples.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.ErrorDiffusionDitherer.StevensonArce
member.summary:
Gets an instance using the hexagonal filter proposed by Stevenson and Arce in 1985. Uses a fairly large, 7x4 matrix, but due to the hexagonal arrangement of the coefficients the processing performance is comparable to a rectangular 5x3 matrix.
See the Examples section for some examples.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.ErrorDiffusionDitherer.Atkinson
member.summary:
Gets an instance using the filter used by the Apple programmer Bill Atkinson. Uses a 4x3 matrix of only 6 effective values, and propagates only the 75% of the quantization error, which may cause total loss of details of light and dark areas (result may seem under- or overexposed) whereas midtones have higher contrast and preserve details better.
See the Examples section for some examples.

to process odd lines right-to-left and even lines left-to-right; to process all lines left-to-right.

However, when quantizing color images with a black and white or grayscale palette, this approach may fail. For example, if the quantizer returns black for a fully saturated blue pixel, the quantization error is zero on the red and green channels and 100% on the blue channel. The problem is that this error cannot be propagated to the neighboring pixels if they have the same color because adding any more blue to already fully saturated blue pixels will not change anything. The following table demonstrates the effect of different strategies:

Quantizing with black and white palette and Floyd-Steinberg dithering, using raster processing. The ripple effect is clearly visible on the coat.
Quantizing with black and white palette and Floyd-Steinberg dithering, using serpentine processing. The ripple effect is gone.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.InterleavedGradientNoiseDitherer
member.summary:
Provides an implementation for applying an interleaved gradient noise pattern to the dithered result. For other noise-like ditherers see the OrderedDitherer.BlueNoise property and the class.
See the Remarks section for details and some examples.

remarks.note: The noise generated by the is not random but based on a formula so using the same source image, quantizer and strength produces always the same result (similarly to the ditherer, which is based on ordered dithering). To dither images with real random noise use the , which applies white noise to the quantized source.
remarks.para:

member.name: T:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.OrderedDitherer
member.summary:
Provides an implementation for dithering patterns that are based on an ordered matrix. Use the static properties of this class to use predefined patterns or the constructor to create a custom ordered ditherer.
See the Remarks section for details and some image examples.

remarks.para: The constructor can be used to create an ordered ditherer using a custom matrix.

Use the static properties to obtain an instance with a predefined pattern. For the best results use the Bayer8x8 or BlueNoise properties. Or you can use the DottedHalftone property for artistic results.

The class offers a very fast dithering technique based on an ordered pattern specified in a matrix of bytes. The more different values the matrix has the more number of different patterns can be mapped to the shades of the original pixels. While quantizing lighter and lighter colors, the different patterns appear in the order of the values in the specified matrix.

The following table demonstrates the effect of the dithering:
Original imageQuantized image
Color hues with alpha gradient
Quantizing with system default 8 BPP palette, no dithering
Quantizing with system default 8 BPP palette and Bayer 8x8 dithering
Quantizing with system default 8 BPP palette and blue noise dithering
Quantizing with system default 8 BPP palette and dotted halftone pattern dithering
Grayscale color shades
Quantizing with black and white palette, no dithering
Quantizing with black and white palette and Bayer 8x8 dithering
Quantizing with black and white palette and blue noise dithering
Quantizing with black and white palette and dotted halftone pattern dithering

Unlike in case of the , ordered dithering does not adjust strength to the quantization error of a pixel but simply uses the specified matrix values based on pixel coordinates to determine the quantized result. Therefore, a strength can be specified (see the constructor and the ConfigureStrength method), whose ideal value depends on the colors that a quantizer can return. If the strength is too low, then banding may appear in the result in place of gradients in the original image; whereas if the strength is too high, then dithering patterns may appear even in colors without quantization error (overdithering).

Every static property in the returns an instance with auto strength, meaning that strength will be calibrated for each dithering session so that neither the black, nor the white colors will suffer from overdithering in the result. The auto value is usually correct if the quantizer returns evenly distributed colors. To obtain an instance with custom strength use the ConfigureStrength method.

The following table demonstrates the effect of different strengths:
Original imageQuantized image
Grayscale color shades
Quantizing with system default 4 BPP palette, no dithering. The asymmetry is due to the uneven distribution of gray shades of this palette.
Quantizing with system default 4 BPP palette and Bayer 8x8 dithering using auto strength. Darker shades have banding.
Quantizing with system default 4 BPP palette and Bayer 8x8 dithering using strength = 0.5. Now there is no banding but white suffers from overdithering.
remarks.note: See the Examples section of the static properties for more examples.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.RandomNoiseDitherer
member.summary:
Provides an implementation for random noise dithering. This class applies a random white noise to the result. For other noise-like ditherers see the OrderedDitherer.BlueNoise property and the class.
See the Remarks section for details and some examples.

remarks.para: The generates some random white noise to the quantized source.
remarks.note: There are also a couple of ditherers with non-random noise-like patterns in this library. See also the OrderedDitherer.BlueNoise property and the class.
remarks.para: To get always the same result for the same source image and quantizer you can specify a seed when initializing a instance. Please note though that specifying a seed prevents parallel processing, which makes performance worse on multi-core systems.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.AnimatedGifConfiguration
member.summary: Represents the configuration for encoding a GIF animation by the GifEncoder.EncodeAnimation method.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.AnimatedGifConfiguration.Size
member.summary:
Gets or sets the desired size of the result animation. If , then size is determined by the first frame. If set explicitly or the input frames can have different sizes, then should also be set accordingly.
Default value: .

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.AnimatedGifConfiguration.SizeHandling
member.summary:
Gets or sets how possibly different input frame sizes are handled.
Default value: .

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.AnimatedGifConfiguration.ReplaceZeroDelays
member.summary:
Gets or sets whether zero delay values are allowed in the result stream, which is usually interpreted as 100 ms by most GIF decoders.
Default value: .
member.value:
If , then zero delay values will be replaced to 100 milliseconds.
If , then zero delays will be preserved and the decoders decide how to interpret them.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.AnimatedGifConfiguration.Quantizer
member.summary:
Gets or sets an optional quantizer to be used for the frames. Using a non- value forces the quantization also of already indexed images. Should use up to 256 colors; otherwise, the result might be quantized further with using the default system 8-bit palette.
Default value: .
member.value:
If , then the possibly existing palette of already indexed input frames are preserved. For frames with a non-indexed pixel format a quantizer returned by the OptimizedPaletteQuantizer.Wu method will be used.
If not , then all frames will be quantized, even the already indexed ones. If does not support transparency, then will be ignored.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.AnimatedGifConfiguration.Ditherer
member.summary:
Gets or sets an optional ditherer to be used when quantizing the frames.
Default value: .

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.AnimatedGifConfiguration.AnimationMode
member.summary:
Gets or sets the looping mode of the animation.
Default value: .
member.value:
If , then the animation will be repeated indefinitely.
If , then the specified frames will be added in both ways so the final animation will be played back and forth.
If , then the animation will be played only once.
The actually supports any positive value less than or equal to UInt16.MaxValue even though they don't have named values in the enumeration.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.AnimatedGifConfiguration.EncodeTransparentBorders
member.summary:
Gets or sets whether the transparent borders of the frames should be encoded as part of the frame.
Default value: .
member.value:
If , then transparent borders of the frames will be considered as image content (and possibly smaller frames will be virtually enlarged, too). This produces a bit larger encoded size but provides better compatibility.
If , then always only the smallest possible non-transparent area will be encoded. Some decoders may not tolerate this option.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.AnimatedGifConfiguration.AllowDeltaFrames
member.summary:
Gets or sets whether it is allowed to encode only the changed part of a frame. In some circumstances the value of this property might be ignored.
Default value: .
member.value:
If , then the encoding time and the required memory may be larger but it allows creating high-color GIF animations. This depends also on the used , though: an allows creating a specific palette for each frame, for example.
If , then all frames will be encoded individually. This provides faster encoding time with lower memory consumption.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.AnimatedGifConfiguration.DeltaTolerance
member.summary:
Gets or sets the allowed maximum tolerance for detecting changes of consecutive frames when is .
Default value: 0.
member.value:
If 0, then even a minimal color difference will be considered as a change to be encoded.
If 255, then nothing will be treated as a change. The animation will have no new frames unless a frame contains new transparent pixels compared to the previous one.
The reasonable range is between 0 and 16 with an optimized quantizer. Predefined quantizers may tolerate larger values (eg. up to 32) with some dithering.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.AnimatedGifConfiguration.ReportOverallProgress
member.summary:
Gets or sets whether to report overall and/or sub-task progress when encoding by GifEncoder.BeginEncodeAnimation and GifEncoder.EncodeAnimationAsync methods and the property is set. When , then both are reported.
Default value: .
member.value:
If , then both overall and sub-task progress are reported. You can filter overall progress steps by considering operations only.
If , then only overall progress steps are reported. Please note that if the count of the instance passed to the constructor cannot be determined in a trivial way, then the maximum value of the steps will be adjusted dynamically.
If , then only sub-task progress steps are reported such as optimizing palette, quantizing and other processing operations.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.AnimatedGifConfiguration.#ctor(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IReadableBitmapData},System.Nullable{System.TimeSpan})

member.name: T:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.GifEncoder
member.summary:
Provides an encoder for GIF image format that supports animation. Use the static members for high-level access or create an instance to control everything manually.
See the Remarks section for details.

remarks.para: The simplest way to create a single-frame GIF image is calling the static EncodeImage method. It can quantize and dither any input source.

The simplest way to create a GIF animation is calling the static EncodeAnimation method. It expects an that describes the frames and delays to be used along with numerous optional configuration such as a specific quantizer and ditherer, looping mode, handling of possible different input image sizes, encoding strategies like allowing delta images or explicitly encoding transparent borders. If you use an and the property is , then you can create really high quality animations allowing more than 256 colors per frame.

Alternatively, you can instantiate the class, which allows you even more control at lower levels. The , and properties should be set before adding the first frame, whereas can be changed before each frame. The AddImage method allows specifying a location for each frame as well as an action to be performed after the delay interval of the corresponding frame is over. You can even write comments to the serialization stream by the AddComments method. When using the AddImage method to add frames you should use already quantized images with indexed pixel format. Non-indexed images will be quantized using the default 8-bit "web-safe" palette without dithering.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.GifEncoder.RepeatCount
member.summary:
Gets or sets the number of repetitions if creating an animation. Set a non- value to add the NETSCAPE2.0 extension to the stream and to indicate that added images should be interpreted as animation frames. Use 0 to loop the animation indefinitely. If , and images are added with 0 delay, then GDI+ handles image as a multi-layer single frame image, though some application (including browsers) still may play them as individual frames.
Default value: .
member.exception: This property cannot be set after adding the first image.

member.summary:
Gets or sets the global palette. If not set, then each added image will be stored along with their own palette. If not , then the palette of the added images are stored only when they are different from the global palette.
Default value: .
member.exception: This property cannot be set after adding the first image.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.GifEncoder.LzwEncoder
member.summary: The LZW Encoder based on the specification as per chapter 22 and Appendix F in https://www.w3.org/Graphics/GIF/spec-gif89a.txt The detailed LZW algorithm is written here: http://giflib.sourceforge.net/whatsinagif/lzw_image_data.html

member.name: T:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.GifEncoder.LzwEncoder.CodeTable
member.summary: Provides the LZW code table implementation. It has been refactored to use open addressing double hashing instead of a regular Dictionary. Some implementation ideas were inspired by Kevin Weiner's Java encoder from here: http://www.java2s.com/Code/Java/2D-Graphics-GUI/AnimatedGifEncoder.htm Basically it uses a variant of Knuth's algorithm along with G. Knott's relatively-prime secondary probe.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.GifEncoder.LzwEncoder.CodeTable.tableSize
member.summary: A prime that provides about 80% occupancy in the code table considering the max used entries when bit size is 12.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.GifEncoder.LzwEncoder.CodeTable.entries
member.summary: Earlier versions used a dictionary as a code table where the key was a span of palette indices. Even with shared underlying buffer memory and optimized GetHashCode/Equals implementation it was much less efficient. Here we can exploit that all prefixes of new codes are already stored so when there is a hash collision we don't need to perform an equality check for the whole segment repeatedly (this is what Dictionary does when there are more entries in the same bucket). Instead, we use double hashing and a match key for equality check: - The primary hash is calculated for the current prefix and is used to select a code table entry - A match key is used for equality check. It is calculated last code + current index combination and is stored along with prefix codes. - If equality check by match key fails (collision), then using a secondary hash to jump from entry to entry. The idea was taken from here: http://www.java2s.com/Code/Java/2D-Graphics-GUI/AnimatedGifEncoder.htm

member.name: M:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.GifEncoder.EncodeImage(KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IReadableBitmapData,System.IO.Stream,KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IQuantizer,KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IDitherer)

remarks.note: This method adjusts the degree of parallelization automatically, blocks the caller, and does not support cancellation or reporting progress. Use the BeginEncodeImage or EncodeImageAsync (in .NET Framework 4.0 and above) methods for asynchronous call and to set up cancellation or for reporting progress.

This method is not a blocking call even if the property of the parameter is 1. The encoding itself cannot be parallelized. The setting affects only the quantizing session if has a non-indexed pixel format, or when is set.
remarks.note: See the Remarks section of the EncodeImage method for more details.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.GifEncoder.EncodeHighColorImage(KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IReadableBitmapData,System.IO.Stream,System.Boolean,KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.Color32,System.Byte)
member.summary:
Encodes the specified as a multi-layered, single frame GIF image and writes it into the specified , preserving its original color depth.
See the Remarks section for details.
member.param: The image data to write. Possible alpha pixels might be blended with but otherwise the color depth will be preserved.
The stream to save the encoded animation into.

to allow scanning the whole image for each layers to be able to re-use the local palette of the current layer.
to expand the initial layer area to the local pixels only. This parameter is optional.
Default value: .

Colors with alpha (transparency), whose Color32.A field is equal to or greater than will be blended with this color during the encoding. The alpha value (Color32.A field) of the specified background color is ignored. This parameter is optional.
Default value: The default value of the type, which has the same RGB values as .

Specifies a threshold value for the Color32.A field, under which a pixel is considered transparent. If 0, then the final composite image will not have transparent pixels. This parameter is optional.
Default value: 128.

remarks.note: This method adjusts the degree of parallelization automatically, blocks the caller, and does not support cancellation or reporting progress. Use the BeginEncodeHighColorImage or EncodeHighColorImageAsync (in .NET Framework 4.0 and above) methods for asynchronous call and to set up cancellation or for reporting progress.

This method produces a GIF image that may have compatibility issues. Though the and types (at least in Windows) support them as expected as well as applications built on GDI+ (such as Windows Paint), many decoders may treat the result as an animation (including browsers).
remarks.para: If is , then both the processing time and memory usage is higher. It helps to minimize the number of layers of the final image; however, the final image size will not be necessarily smaller, especially for true color images.

If is , then each layer is attempted to be as compact as possible. It allows a very fast processing with lower memory usage. Though it usually produces more layers, the final size will not be necessarily larger, especially for true color images.
remarks.note: You can prequantize true color images using a 16-bit quantizer (with or without dithering) to produce fairly compact, still high color GIF images. For such images the parameter with value typically produces more compact results. You can consider using the Argb1555 quantizer for images with transparency, or the Rgb565 quantizer for non-transparent images.
remarks.para: To encode an you can use also the ImageExtensions.SaveAsHighColorGif methods.
To create a multi-layered image completely manually you can create a instance that provides a lower level access.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.AnimationFramesSizeHandling
member.summary: Represents the strategy to be used with frames of different sizes.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.AnimationFramesSizeHandling.ErrorIfDiffers
member.summary: Specifies that if an input frame has a different size, then an exception should be thrown.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.AnimationFramesSizeHandling.Center
member.summary: Specifies that smaller or larger frames should be centered. Possibly exceeding areas will be clipped.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.AnimationFramesSizeHandling.Resize
member.summary: Specifies that frames should be resized to the actual size of the animation.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.AnimationMode
member.summary: Represents the looping mode of an animation.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.AnimationMode.PingPong
member.summary: Specifies that added frames should be played back and forth.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.AnimationMode.Repeat
member.summary: Specifies that the animation should be looped.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.AnimationMode.PlayOnce
member.summary: Specifies that the animation should be played only once.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.GifCompressionMode
member.summary: Represents the compression behavior of the class.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.GifCompressionMode.Auto
member.summary: Represents the automatic adaptive mode. The internally used code table might be regularly cleared.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.GifCompressionMode.DoNotClear
member.summary: Indicates that once the internally used code table is full, it is not maintained anymore and all remaining codes are written using 12 bit code size. If codes so far can be re-used, then the result can be more compact than with mode; otherwise, the result can be even longer than in mode. This option might not be tolerated by some decoders.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.GifCompressionMode.DoNotIncreaseBitSize
member.summary: Indicates that all written codes must use the same bit size (3 to 9 bits, depending on palette size). It uses less memory but it may lead to poor compression, especially with palettes using no more than 4 colors.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.GifCompressionMode.Uncompressed
member.summary: Indicates that the should not use any compression. It uses the least memory but the result can be really long.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.GifGraphicDisposalMethod
member.summary: Indicates the way in which the graphic is to be treated after being displayed.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.GifGraphicDisposalMethod.NotSpecified
member.summary: No disposal specified. The decoder is not required to take any action.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.GifGraphicDisposalMethod.DoNotDispose
member.summary: Do not dispose. The graphic is to be left in place.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.GifGraphicDisposalMethod.RestoreToBackground
member.summary: Restore to background color. The area used by the graphic must be restored to the background color. If there is no global palette, or the corresponding image has transparent color, then the virtual screen is always cleared to transparent.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.GifGraphicDisposalMethod.RestoreToPrevious
member.summary: Restore to previous. The decoder is required to restore the area overwritten by the graphic with what was there prior to rendering the graphic.

member.summary:
Gets the clone of the specified with identical size and the specified and color settings. This method is similar to but as the result is a managed instance every is supported on any platform.

member.param: An instance to be cloned.
The desired pixel format of the result.

If does not support alpha or supports only single-bit alpha, then specifies the color of the background. Source pixels with alpha, which will be opaque in the result will be blended with this color. The Color32.A property of the background color is ignored. This parameter is optional.
Default value: The default value of the type, which has the same RGB values as .

If can represent only single-bit alpha or is an indexed format and the target palette contains a transparent color, then specifies a threshold value for the Color32.A property, under which the color is considered transparent. If 0, then the result will not have transparent pixels. This parameter is optional.
Default value: 128.
member.returns: An instance that represents the clone of the specified .

remarks.note: This method adjusts the degree of parallelization automatically, blocks the caller, and does not support cancellation or reporting progress. Use the or (in .NET Framework 4.0 and above) methods for asynchronous call and to adjust parallelization, set up cancellation and for reporting progress.
remarks.para: This overload automatically quantizes colors if represents a narrower set of colors than . To use a custom quantizer use the overloads with an parameter.

Color depth of wide-color formats (, , , ) can be preserved only between the same pixel formats. If they are different, or is from a on Windows, which uses 13 bits-per-pixel channels, then colors might be quantized to 32bpp ones during the operation.

If represents an indexed format, then the target palette is taken from if it also has a palette of no more entries than the target indexed format can have; otherwise, a default palette will be used based on . To specify the desired palette of the result use the overload.
remarks.note: See the Examples section of the extension method for some examples. The ConvertPixelFormat extensions work the same way for s as the Clone extensions for instances.

Color depth of wide-color formats (, , , ) can be preserved only between the same pixel formats if there is no specified. If pixel formats are different, or is from a on Windows, which uses 13 bits-per-pixel channels, then colors might be quantized to 32bpp ones during the operation.
remarks.note: See the Examples section of the extension method for some examples. The ConvertPixelFormat extensions work the same way for s as the Clone extensions for instances.

member.summary:
Copies the into the without scaling and blending. This method works between any pair of source and target s and supports quantizing and dithering. To draw a bitmap data into another one with blending use the DrawInto methods instead.
See the Remarks section for details.
member.param: The source to be copied into the .
The target into which should be copied.

The target location. Target size will be always the same as the source size. This parameter is optional.
Default value: Point.Empty.

An instance to be used. If not specified, then the copying operation might automatically pick a quantizer based on . This parameter is optional.
Default value: .

The ditherer to be used. Might be ignored if is not specified and format has at least 24 bits-per-pixel size. This parameter is optional.
Default value: .

remarks.note: This method adjusts the degree of parallelization automatically, blocks the caller, and does not support cancellation or reporting progress. Use the BeginCopyTo or CopyToAsync (in .NET Framework 4.0 and above) methods for asynchronous call and to adjust parallelization, set up cancellation and for reporting progress.
remarks.para: The copied area is automatically clipped if its size or makes it impossible to completely fit in the .

If can represent a narrower set of colors, then the result will be automatically quantized to the colors of the , even if there is no specified. To use dithering a must be explicitly specified though.
If is specified but it uses more/different colors than can represent, then the result will eventually quantized to , though the result may have a poorer quality than expected.

member.summary:
Draws the into the without scaling, using blending. This method is similar to Graphics.DrawImage methods, except that this one always preserves the source size in pixels, works between any pair of source and target s and supports quantizing and dithering. For scaling use the overloads with targetRectangle and parameters. To copy a bitmap data into another one without blending use the CopyTo methods instead.
See the Remarks section for details.
member.param: The source to be drawn into the .
The target into which should be drawn.

The target location. Target size will be always the same as the source size. This parameter is optional.

Default value: .

The ditherer to be used for the drawing. Might be ignored if is not specified and format has at least 24 bits-per-pixel size. This parameter is optional.
Default value: .

remarks.note: This method adjusts the degree of parallelization automatically, blocks the caller, and does not support cancellation or reporting progress. Use the or (in .NET Framework 4.0 and above) methods for asynchronous call and to adjust parallelization, set up cancellation and for reporting progress.
remarks.para: The image to be drawn is automatically clipped if its size or makes it impossible to completely fit in the .
must be an because it must be readable if blending is necessary. For write-only instances you can use the CopyTo methods.

Clips the specified using the specified . Unlike the Clone methods, this one returns a wrapper, providing access only to the specified region of the original .

A that specifies a region within the .
to dispose when the result is disposed; otherwise, .
member.returns: An that provides access only to the specified region withing the .
member.exception: has no overlapping region with source bounds.

remarks.para: The property of the returned instance can be 0, indicating that the ReadRaw method cannot be used. It can occur if the left edge of the clipping is not zero.

Even if property of the returned instance is a nonzero value it can happen that it is too low to access all columns by the ReadRaw method. It can occur with indexed s if the right edge of the clipping is not on byte boundary.

remarks.note: This method adjusts the degree of parallelization automatically, blocks the caller, and does not support cancellation or reporting progress. Use the or (in .NET Framework 4.0 and above) methods for asynchronous call and to adjust parallelization, set up cancellation and for reporting progress.
remarks.para: Similarly to the Bitmap.MakeTransparent method, this one uses the bottom-left pixel to determine the background color, which must be completely opaque; otherwise, just an exact clone of will be returned.
This method always returns a new with pixel format.
To attempt to make an transparent without creating a new instance use the MakeTransparent method.
To force replacing even non-completely opaque pixels use the overload instead.
remarks.note: Please note that unlike the MakeOpaque method, this one changes exactly one color shade without any tolerance. For any customization use the Clone method with a quantizer created by the PredefinedColorsQuantizer.FromCustomFunction method.

member.summary:
Saves the content of this into the specified .
See the Remarks section for details.
member.param: The to save.
The stream to save the bitmap data into.

remarks.note: This method blocks the caller, and does not support cancellation or reporting progress. Use the BeginSave or SaveAsync (in .NET Framework 4.0 and above) methods for asynchronous call and to set up cancellation or for reporting progress.
remarks.para: To reload the content use the BitmapDataFactory.Load method.
The saved content always preserves so the BitmapDataFactory.Load method can restore it the same way on any platform.
remarks.note: If represents the bitmap data of a native with , or , then on Windows the actual color depth is quantized to 32bpp because these formats have a different raw interpretation than managed bitmaps used by KGySoft Drawing Libraries.

A that specifies a region within the .
to dispose when the result is disposed; otherwise, .
member.returns: An that provides access only to the specified region withing the .
member.exception: has no overlapping region with source bounds.

remarks.para: The property of the returned instance can be 0, indicating that the ReadRaw/WriteRaw method cannot be used. It can occur if the left edge of the clipping is not zero.

Even if property of the returned instance is a nonzero value it can happen that it is too low to access all columns by the ReadRaw/WriteRaw methods. It can occur with indexed s if the right edge of the clipping is not on byte boundary.

remarks.para: This method quantizes the specified in place (its original content will be overwritten). To return a new instance use the Clone extension method instead.
If the or the palette of is not compatible with the colors of the specified , then the result may not be correct.
If has already the same set of colors that the specified , then it can happen that calling this method does not change the at all.

list.item:

To use an optimized palette of up to 256 colors adjusted for see the class.

member.summary:
If possible, makes the background of this transparent, taking the bottom-left pixel as the background color. If the does not support transparency, then the pixels that have the same color as the bottom-left pixel will be set to the of .
See the Remarks section for details.
member.param: The to make transparent.

remarks.note: This method adjusts the degree of parallelization automatically, blocks the caller, and does not support cancellation or reporting progress. Use the or (in .NET Framework 4.0 and above) methods for asynchronous call and to adjust parallelization, set up cancellation and for reporting progress.
remarks.para: This method calls the ReplaceColor method internally.
Similarly to the Bitmap.MakeTransparent method, this one uses the bottom-left pixel to determine the background color, which must be completely opaque; otherwise, will not be changed.

Unlike the Bitmap.MakeTransparent method, this one preserves the original . If does not support transparency and cannot set either, then every occurrence of the color of the bottom-left pixel will be changed to the of . To make such bitmaps transparent use the ToTransparent method instead, which returns a new instance with .
To force replacing even non-completely opaque pixels use the overload instead.
remarks.note: Please note that unlike the MakeOpaque method, this one changes exactly one color shade without any tolerance. For any customization use the TransformColors method instead.

member.summary:
Clears the content of the specified and fills it with the specified .
This method is similar to Graphics.Clear except that this one supports any and also dithering.
member.param: The to be cleared.

A that represents the desired result color of the . If it has transparency, which is not supported by of , then the result might be either completely transparent (depends also on ), or the color will be blended with .

The ditherer to be used for the clearing. Has no effect if of has at least 24 bits-per-pixel size. This parameter is optional.

remarks.note: This method adjusts the degree of parallelization automatically, blocks the caller, and does not support cancellation or reporting progress. Use the BeginClear or ClearAsync (in .NET Framework 4.0 and above) methods for asynchronous call and to adjust parallelization, set up cancellation and for reporting progress.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IBitmapData
member.summary:
Represents the raw data of a bitmap. To create a managed instance use the class. To obtain a readable or writable instance for a native instance call the GetReadableBitmapData, GetWritableBitmapData or GetReadWriteBitmapData extension methods.
See the Remarks section of the GetReadWriteBitmapData method for details and examples.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IBitmapData.Height
member.summary: Gets the height of the current instance in pixels.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IBitmapData.Width
member.summary: Gets the width of the current instance in pixels.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IBitmapData.PixelFormat
member.summary:
Gets the of the current instance.
See the Remarks section for details.

remarks.para: The value of this property determines how the raw underlying values should be interpreted if the pixels are accessed by the ReadRaw or WriteRaw methods. Otherwise, in most cases using the members of the interfaces derived from the and interfaces work seamlessly.
If this property returns an indexed format (, or ), then the property returns a non- value.
remarks.note:
If this instance represents a native , then on some platforms this property can return a different from the Image.PixelFormat property of the original image.
For details and further information about the possible usable s on different platforms see the Remarks section of the ConvertPixelFormat method.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IBitmapData.Palette
member.summary: Gets a instance representing the colors of the owner if it has an indexed , or if the owner is not an indexed one. For indexed bitmaps the property returns , or .

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IBitmapData.RowSize
member.summary:
Gets the size of a row in bytes, or zero, if this instance does not have an actual raw buffer to access. Otherwise, is similar to BitmapData.Stride but this property never returns a negative value.
See the Remarks section for details.

remarks.para: This property can be useful when accessing the bitmap data by the ReadRaw or WriteRaw methods.
As can represent also a managed bitmap data, row size is not guaranteed to be a multiple of 4.

note.para: This property can return 0 if the current instance represents a bitmap data without actual raw data or represents a clipped region where the left edge of the clipping has an offset compared to the original bitmap data.

Even if this property returns a nonzero value, it is possible that raw access does not cover the few last columns. This may occur in case of indexed s if the bitmap data is clipped and the right edge of the clipping does not fall at byte boundary.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IBitmapData.BackColor
member.summary:
When accessing pixels of indexed bitmaps, or setting pixels of bitmaps without alpha support, gets the color of the background. For example, when setting color values with alpha, which are considered opaque, they will be blended with this color before setting the pixel.
See the Remarks section of the GetReadWriteBitmapData extension method for details and examples.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IBitmapData.AlphaThreshold
member.summary: If this represents a bitmap with single bit alpha or with a palette that has a transparent color, then gets a threshold value for the Color32.A property, under which the color is considered transparent. If 0, then the pixels to be set will never be transparent.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IDitherer
member.summary:
Represents a ditherer that can be used to dither the result of a quantizing session.
For built-in implementations see the , , and classes.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IDitherer.InitializeReliesOnContent
member.summary:
Gets whether Initialize relies on the actual content of the source to be dithered.
See the Remarks section for details.

remarks.para: This property should return , if Initialize method relies on the exact content to be dithered in order to make the GetDitheredColor method work properly.

If this property returns , then Initialize will be called with an instance, whose and properties can be used but the actual content might be different from the one will be used when calling the GetDitheredColor method.

The return value of this property may affect the performance of some drawing operations where returning forces the source and target images to be blended together before dithering the result, while returning allows the ditherer to be initialized with the source image and let the GetDitheredColor method to be called with colors that are blended on-the-fly during the dithering.

Default value: .
member.returns: An instance that can be used to dither the result of the specified applied to the specified .

member.summary: Gets whether this ditherer allows only sequential processing (line by line). Even returning does not guarantee that every pixel will be queried. It just enforces that queried rows are processed sequentially.
member.value: If , then the GetDitheredColor method will be called sequentially for each queried pixels. If , then the GetDitheredColor method can be called concurrently for any pixels.

For built-in implementations see the and classes.

member.summary: Gets a that is compatible with this . It is recommended to return the format with the lowest bits-per-pixel value that is still compatible with this instance.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IQuantizer.InitializeReliesOnContent
member.summary:
Gets whether Initialize relies on the actual content of the source to be quantized.
See the Remarks section for details.

remarks.para: This property should return , if Initialize method relies on the exact content to be quantized in order to generate a palette and make the GetQuantizedColor method work properly.

If this property returns , then Initialize will be called with an instance, whose and properties can be used but the actual content might be different from the one will be used when calling the GetQuantizedColor method.

The return value of this property may affect the performance of some drawing operations where returning forces the source and target images to be blended together before quantizing the result, while returning allows the quantizer to be initialized with the source image and let the GetQuantizedColor method to be called with colors that are blended on-the-fly during the quantization.

Contains information for asynchronous processing about the current operation. This parameter is optional.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IQuantizingSession
member.summary: Represents a disposable quantizing session returned by the IQuantizer.Initialize method that is used to quantize (reduce the colors) of a specific source.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IQuantizingSession.Palette
member.summary: Gets the palette containing the colors of the quantized result. Expected to be called if the result of the quantization is an indexed image and in that case should not contain more than 256 colors. If this is not limited to use up to 256 colors, then this property can return .

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IQuantizingSession.BackColor
member.summary:
Gets the background color for this . When the GetQuantizedColor is called with a color with alpha, which is considered opaque, then it will be blended with this color before quantizing.
See also the Remarks section of the property for details.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IQuantizingSession.AlphaThreshold
member.summary:
If this can produce transparent pixels, then gets the alpha threshold value that can be used to determine whether a color with alpha should be considered transparent or should be blended with .
See the Remarks section for details.

remarks.para: If this can produce transparent pixels, and GetQuantizedColor is called with a color, whose Color32.A field is lower than the threshold, then the returned color will be transparent.

If this cannot produce transparent pixels, or GetQuantizedColor is called with a color, whose Color32.A field is greater than or equal to the threshold, then the returned color will be will be blended with before quantizing.
If is 0, then the quantized color will never be transparent.
If is 255, then only fully opaque colors will not be considered transparent.

member.returns: The quantized color.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.OptimizedPaletteQuantizer
member.summary:
Represents a quantizer that can generate an optimized set of colors best matching to the original image. Use the static methods to retrieve an instance. For using predefined colors see the class.
See the Remarks section for details and results comparison.

remarks.para: The class can be used to reduce colors of a using a palette of up to 256 colors where the palette entries are optimized for the quantized image.
This class supports palette optimization by three different algorithms (see the Octree, MedianCut and Wu methods)

The following table compares the algorithms supported by the class:
OctreeMedianCutWu
Speed Slower than the Wu's algorithm but faster than MedianCut. This is the slowest one of the three algorithms. This is the fastest one of the three algorithms (still much slower though than the quantizers of the class).
Memory consumption* Generating the palette may consume quite a large amount of memory but it also depends on the number of different colors of the source image and the requested color count. Generating the palette may consume quite a large amount of memory but it also depends on the number of different colors of the source image and the requested color count. Quite large memory consumption even if the source has few colors and the requested color count is small.
Quality
Usually poorer quality for smaller palettes (below 16 colors).
Banding may appear in images with large low-frequency areas (eg. sky or water in photos).
Balanced quality for larger palettes and photo-like images.
Usually very good quality even for smaller palettes.t
Excellent, nearly banding-free results with images with large low-frequency areas (eg. sky or water in photos).
May provide a slightly poorer quality for small areas with unique colors (eg. a smaller human face in a large photo).
Usually very good quality even for smaller palettes.
Banding may appear in images with large low-frequency areas (eg. sky or water in photos), though not as heavily as in case of the Octree algorithm (and it can be blended by dithering anyway). The banding may appear even if the image uses just a few tones because Wu's algorithm generates colors from the RGB555 color space (which uses 32 shades of each color channels).
Very good quality for photo-like images, especially if the image has no homogeneous low-frequency areas.
*Memory consumption mentioned in the table affects palette generation only. That occurs when the IQuantizer.Initialize method of an instance is called. As soon as this method returns with an instance, the memory mentioned in the table can be reclaimed.
On the other hand, the can also consume a large amount of memory during the quantization because its caches the quantization results of the source image pixels, though this caching does not depend on the chosen algorithm and can also be reclaimed when the is disposed.
So keeping a reference to an consumes almost no memory when there is no active quantization session in progress.

The following table compares the results of the instances returned by the Octree, MedianCut and Wu methods. For better comparison none of the images are dithered in the examples, though the visual quality can be improved by using dithering. See the , , and classes for some built-in implementations.
Original imageQuantized image
Color hues with alpha gradient
Octree algorithm, 256 colors, silver background, zero alpha threshold
MedianCut algorithm, 256 colors, silver background, zero alpha threshold
Wu's algorithm, 256 colors, silver background, zero alpha threshold
Information icon with transparency
Octree algorithm, 4 colors, silver background, zero alpha threshold
MedianCut algorithm, 4 colors, silver background, zero alpha threshold
Wu's algorithm, 4 colors, silver background, zero alpha threshold
Octree algorithm, 256 colors, black background, alpha threshold = 128. Banding appeared in the result.
MedianCut algorithm, 256 colors, black background, alpha threshold = 128. Practically there is no banding in the result.
Wu's algorithm, 256 colors, black background, alpha threshold = 128. A slight banding can be observed, as if the image was quantized by the PredefinedColorsQuantizer.Argb1555 quantizer (see the details in the comparison table above).

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.OptimizedPaletteQuantizer.WuQuantizer.sqrTable
member.summary: Just a lookup table for squared values between 0..255

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.OptimizedPaletteQuantizer.WuQuantizer.m2
member.summary: The squared moment values of color RGB values. After building the histogram by an element of this array can be interpreted as m2[r, g, b] = sum over voxel of c^2*P(c) and after it contains cumulative moments. The strictly taken Bernoulli probability is actually multiplied by image size. but it does not matter here. Effective histogram elements are in 1.. along each axis, element 0 is just for base or marginal value. Values are floats just because of the possible big ranges due to squared values.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.OptimizedPaletteQuantizer.WuQuantizer.wt
member.summary: The counts of voxels of the 3D color cubes in each position. The same applies as for except that after values are interpreted as wt[r, g, b] = sum over voxel of P(c)

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.OptimizedPaletteQuantizer.WuQuantizer.mr
member.summary: The moment values of red color components. The same applies as for except that after values are interpreted as wt[r, g, b] = sum over voxel of r*P(c)

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.OptimizedPaletteQuantizer.WuQuantizer.mg
member.summary: The moment values of green color components. The same applies as for except that after values are interpreted as wt[r, g, b] = sum over voxel of g*P(c)

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.OptimizedPaletteQuantizer.WuQuantizer.mb
member.summary: The moment values of green color components. The same applies as for except that after values are interpreted as wt[r, g, b] = sum over voxel of b*P(c)

member.name: M:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.OptimizedPaletteQuantizer.WuQuantizer.HistogramToMoments
member.summary: Computing cumulative moments from the histogram.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.OptimizedPaletteQuantizer.WuQuantizer.Var(KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.OptimizedPaletteQuantizer.WuQuantizer.Box)
member.summary: Compute the weighted variance of a box. Note: as with the raw statistics, this is actually the variance multiplied by image size

member.name: M:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.PredefinedColorsQuantizer.Argb8888(System.Drawing.Color,System.Byte)
member.summary:
Gets a instance that quantizes colors to the 32-bit ARGB color space.
See the Remarks section for details and some examples.
member.param:
Determines the property of the returned quantizer. Considering that this quantizer can return alpha colors it has effect only when the returned quantizer is used with a ditherer that does not support partial transparency. The Color.A property of the background color is ignored. This parameter is optional.
Default value: , which has the same RGB values as .

Specifies a threshold value for the Color.A property, under which a quantized color is considered completely transparent. If 0, then the quantized colors will preserve their original alpha value. This parameter is optional.
Default value: 128.
member.returns: A instance that quantizes colors to the 32-bit ARGB color space.

remarks.para: If is zero, then the returned instance is practically just a pass-through filter in the 32-bit color space and it is effective only for some bitmap data operations (eg. Clone), which could possibly preserve wide color information (s with 48/64 bpp) without specifying a quantizer.
If is not zero, then every partially transparent pixel with lower Color.A value than the threshold will turn completely transparent.
This quantizer fits well for s with pixel format.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.PredefinedColorsQuantizer.Rgb888(System.Drawing.Color)
member.summary:
Gets a instance that quantizes colors to 24-bit ones where each color component is encoded in 8 bits.
See the Remarks section for details and some examples.
member.param:
Colors with alpha (transparency) will be blended with this color before quantization. The Color.A property of the background color is ignored. This parameter is optional.
Default value: , which has the same RGB values as .
member.returns: A instance that quantizes colors to 24-bit ones where each color component is encoded in 8 bits.

remarks.para: The returned instance can return up to 2563 (16,777,216) colors. It practically just removes transparency and does not change colors without alpha.
This quantizer fits well for s with pixel format.
remarks.note: For more information about the possible usable s on different platforms see the Remarks section of the ConvertPixelFormat extension method.

to map any color directly to an index instead of searching for a nearest color, which is very fast but without dithering may end up in a noticeably poorer result and higher contrast; to perform a lookup to determine nearest colors, which may be slower but more accurate. This parameter is optional.

Default value: , which has the same RGB values as .
member.returns: A instance that quantizes colors to 8-bit grayscale ones.

remarks.para: The returned quantizer uses direct mapping to grayscale colors based on human perception, which makes quantization very fast while it is very accurate at the same time.
The returned instance can return up to 256 possible shades of gray.
The palette of this quantizer does not contain the transparent color. To make an image grayscale with transparency you can use the ToGrayscale and MakeGrayscale extension methods.
